mn60:1.1.comm: This sutta subverts the imagery of gambling by reasoning towards logical certitude in a world of apparently random chances. Gambling was a major feature of Vedic culture, with the moving confession of Rig Veda 10.34 recounting the thrill and loss of the game. The gods were invoked to ensure success (Atharvaveda 7.109). Even kings bowed to the dice (Rig Veda 10.34.8), so that the Rājasūya consecration ceremony is secured with a (loaded) game of dice (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.4.4.6, 23). Numerous tales of kings losing their realms at dice, most notably Yudhiṣṭhira in the Mahābhārata, show that the power and danger of gambling was not merely symbolic.

mn60:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena sālā nāma kosalānaṃ brāhmaṇagāmo tadavasari.
mn60:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Sālā.
mn60:1.2.comm: The same framing narrative recurs at MN 41, where the topic of rebirth is also at stake.

mn60:2.1.eng: The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard:

mn60:2.2.pli: “samaṇo khalu bho gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ sālaṃ anuppatto.
mn60:2.2.eng: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

mn60:2.3.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

mn60:2.4.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
mn60:2.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

mn60:2.5.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
mn60:2.5.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

mn60:2.6.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
mn60:2.6.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

mn60:2.7.pli: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī”ti.
mn60:2.7.eng: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

mn60:3.1.pli: Atha kho sāleyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā appekacce bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu; sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Appekacce bhagavato santike nāmagottaṃ sāvetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho sāleyyake brāhmaṇagahapatike bhagavā etadavoca:
mn60:3.1.eng: Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. The Buddha said to them:

mn60:4.1.pli: “atthi pana vo, gahapatayo, koci manāpo satthā yasmiṃ vo ākāravatī saddhā paṭiladdhā”ti?
mn60:4.1.eng: “So, householders, is there any teacher you’re happy with, in whom you have acquired grounded faith?”
mn60:4.1.comm: The Brahmanical community was in a period of questioning and transition, with multiple different perspectives offered by both Brahmins and ascetics.

mn60:4.2.pli: “Natthi kho no, bhante, koci manāpo satthā yasmiṃ no ākāravatī saddhā paṭiladdhā”ti.

mn60:4.3.pli: “Manāpaṃ vo, gahapatayo, satthāraṃ alabhantehi ayaṃ apaṇṇako dhammo samādāya vattitabbo.
mn60:4.3.eng: “Since you haven’t found a teacher you’re happy with, you should undertake and implement this unfailing teaching.
mn60:4.3.comm: While the contextual sense of the key term apaṇṇaka (“unfailing”) is clear, the etymology has proven a puzzle. I propose that it is a gambling term, and paṇṇa appears as a form of the number five. While a set of four dice was “perfect”, the fifth “losing” (kali) die was all-powerful, since just one extra die meant you lose everything (Rig Veda 10.34.2, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.4.4.6). Apaṇṇaka is therefore literally a “set without a fifth” and metaphorically “without fail”.

mn60:4.4.pli: Apaṇṇako hi, gahapatayo, dhammo samatto samādinno, so vo bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
mn60:4.4.eng: For when the unfailing teaching is undertaken, it will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.

mn60:4.5.eng: And what is the unfailing teaching?

mn60:5.1.pli: Santi, gahapatayo, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:5.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn60:5.2.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ; natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, natthi ayaṃ loko, natthi paro loko; natthi mātā, natthi pitā; natthi sattā opapātikā; natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammā paṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
mn60:5.2.eng: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
mn60:5.2.comm: At DN 2:23.2 this is presented as the moral view of Ajita of the Hair Blanket, who justifies it with a materialist theory.

mn60:6.1.pli: Tesaṃyeva kho, gahapatayo, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ujuvipaccanīkavādā.
mn60:6.1.eng: And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this.

mn60:6.3.pli: ‘atthi dinnaṃ, atthi yiṭṭhaṃ, atthi hutaṃ; atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko; atthi ayaṃ loko, atthi paro loko; atthi mātā, atthi pitā; atthi sattā opapātikā; atthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammā paṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
mn60:6.3.eng: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
mn60:6.3.comm: The positive side is of course the Buddha’s view.

mn60:6.5.eng: Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”

mn60:7.1.pli: “Tatra, gahapatayo, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:7.1.eng: “Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

mn60:7.2.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ …pe… ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti
mn60:7.2.eng: there’s no meaning in giving, etc.

mn60:7.3.pli: tesametaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—yamidaṃ kāyasucaritaṃ, vacīsucaritaṃ, manosucaritaṃ—ime tayo kusale dhamme abhinivajjetvā yamidaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ, vacīduccaritaṃ, manoduccaritaṃ—ime tayo akusale dhamme samādāya vattissanti.
mn60:7.3.eng: You can expect that they will shun good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and undertake and implement bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn60:7.5.pli: Na hi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā passanti akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ vodānapakkhaṃ.
mn60:7.5.eng: Because those ascetics and brahmins don’t see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, sordidness, and corruption, or that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.

mn60:8.1.pli: Santaṃyeva pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘natthi paro loko’ tissa diṭṭhi hoti; sāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi.
mn60:8.1.eng: Moreover, since there actually is another world, their view that there is no other world is wrong view.

mn60:8.2.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘natthi paro loko’ti saṅkappeti; svāssa hoti micchāsaṅkappo.
mn60:8.2.eng: Since there actually is another world, their thought that there is no other world is wrong thought.

mn60:8.3.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘natthi paro loko’ti vācaṃ bhāsati; sāssa hoti micchāvācā.
mn60:8.3.eng: Since there actually is another world, their speech that there is no other world is wrong speech.

mn60:8.4.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘natthi paro loko’ti āha; ye te arahanto paralokaviduno tesamayaṃ paccanīkaṃ karoti.
mn60:8.4.eng: Since there actually is another world, in saying that there is no other world they contradict those perfected ones who know the other world.

mn60:8.5.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘natthi paro loko’ti paraṃ saññāpeti; sāssa hoti asaddhammasaññatti.
mn60:8.5.eng: Since there actually is another world, in persuading another that there is no other world they are persuading them to accept an untrue teaching.

mn60:8.6.pli: Tāya ca pana asaddhammasaññattiyā attānukkaṃseti, paraṃ vambheti.
mn60:8.6.eng: And on account of that they glorify themselves and put others down.

mn60:8.7.pli: Iti pubbeva kho panassa susīlyaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, dussīlyaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ—
mn60:8.7.eng: So they give up their former ethical conduct and are established in unethical conduct.

mn60:8.8.pli: ayañca micchādiṭṭhi micchāsaṅkappo micchāvācā ariyānaṃ paccanīkatā asaddhammasaññatti attukkaṃsanā paravambhanā. Evamassime aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti micchādiṭṭhipaccayā.
mn60:8.8.eng: And that is how these many bad, unskillful qualities come to be with wrong view as condition—wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, contradicting the noble ones, persuading others to accept untrue teachings, and glorifying oneself and putting others down.

mn60:9.1.pli: Tatra, gahapatayo, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati:
mn60:9.1.eng: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:

mn60:9.2.pli: ‘sace kho natthi paro loko evamayaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo kāyassa bhedā sotthimattānaṃ karissati;
mn60:9.2.eng: ‘If there is no other world, when this individual person’s body breaks up they will keep themselves safe.
mn60:9.2.comm: Given that they no longer exist, how are they safe? Bodhi’s “will have made himself safe” is unlikely, as it is future perfect, a rare sense that requires the past participle. Anyway he hasn’t “made himself” anything, he just happen to live in a world without moral consequences. Horner notes the problem without offering a solution, there are no parallels, and commentaries are silent. I think the text is corrupt.

mn60:9.3.pli: sace kho atthi paro loko, evamayaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:9.3.eng: And if there is another world, when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn60:9.4.pli: Kāmaṃ kho pana māhu paro loko, hotu nesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ;
mn60:9.4.eng: But let us grant that those who say that there is no other world are correct.
mn60:9.4.comm: The syntax of this sentence is tricky. Kāmaṁ is “willingly”, which together with hotu conveys the sense “let us grant …”. Māhu resolves to mā ahu, a simple negation rather than a prohibition. For kāmaṁ with mā and imperative, compare SN 11.4:7.1.

mn60:9.5.pli: atha ca panāyaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ gārayho—dussīlo purisapuggalo micchādiṭṭhi natthikavādo’ti.
mn60:9.5.eng: Regardless, that individual is still criticized by sensible people in this very life as being an immoral individual of wrong view, a nihilist.’
mn60:9.5.comm: “Nihilist” is natthikavāda, “one whose doctrine is that there is nothing”. While this view is discussed many times in the suttas, the word natthikavāda is elsewhere only applied to a specific pair of persons, Vassa and Bhañña of Ukkalā (MN 117:38.1, SN 22.62:13.2, AN 4.30:8.2).

mn60:9.6.pli: Sace kho attheva paro loko, evaṃ imassa bhoto purisapuggalassa ubhayattha kaliggaho—
mn60:9.6.eng: But if there really is another world, they hold a losing hand on both counts.

mn60:9.7.pli: yañca diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ gārayho, yañca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:9.7.eng: For they are criticized by sensible people in this very life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn60:9.8.pli: Evamassāyaṃ apaṇṇako dhammo dussamatto samādinno, ekaṃsaṃ pharitvā tiṭṭhati, riñcati kusalaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
mn60:9.8.eng: They have wrongly undertaken this unfailing teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of one side only, leaving out the skillful premise.
mn60:9.8.comm: It is difficult to choose between “skillful” and “wholesome” as renderings for kusala. “Skillful” sticks closer to the root sense, while “wholesome” is more idiomatic. But the context here well illustrates that the root sense is still alive in the language, as the “skillful” option is that which wisely aligns cause and effect with one’s own well-being.

mn60:10.1.pli: Tatra, gahapatayo, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:10.1.eng: Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

mn60:10.2.pli: ‘atthi dinnaṃ …pe… ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti
mn60:10.2.eng: there is meaning in giving, etc.

mn60:10.3.pli: tesametaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—yamidaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ, vacīduccaritaṃ, manoduccaritaṃ—ime tayo akusale dhamme abhinivajjetvā yamidaṃ kāyasucaritaṃ, vacīsucaritaṃ, manosucaritaṃ—ime tayo kusale dhamme samādāya vattissanti.
mn60:10.3.eng: You can expect that they will shun bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and undertake and implement good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn60:10.5.pli: Passanti hi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ vodānapakkhaṃ.
mn60:10.5.eng: Because those ascetics and brahmins see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, sordidness, and corruption, and that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.

mn60:11.1.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘atthi paro loko’ tissa diṭṭhi hoti; sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
mn60:11.1.eng: Moreover, since there actually is another world, their view that there is another world is right view.

mn60:11.2.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘atthi paro loko’ti saṅkappeti; svāssa hoti sammāsaṅkappo.
mn60:11.2.eng: Since there actually is another world, their thought that there is another world is right thought.

mn60:11.3.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘atthi paro loko’ti vācaṃ bhāsati; sāssa hoti sammāvācā.
mn60:11.3.eng: Since there actually is another world, their speech that there is another world is right speech.

mn60:11.4.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘atthi paro loko’ti āha; ye te arahanto paralokaviduno tesamayaṃ na paccanīkaṃ karoti.
mn60:11.4.eng: Since there actually is another world, in saying that there is another world they don’t contradict those perfected ones who know the other world.

mn60:11.5.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana paraṃ lokaṃ ‘atthi paro loko’ti paraṃ saññāpeti; sāssa hoti saddhammasaññatti.
mn60:11.5.eng: Since there actually is another world, in persuading another that there is another world they are persuading them to accept a true teaching.

mn60:11.6.pli: Tāya ca pana saddhammasaññattiyā nevattānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.
mn60:11.6.eng: And on account of that they don’t glorify themselves or put others down.

mn60:11.7.pli: Iti pubbeva kho panassa dussīlyaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, susīlyaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ—
mn60:11.7.eng: So they give up their former unethical conduct and are established in ethical conduct.

mn60:11.8.pli: ayañca sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā ariyānaṃ apaccanīkatā saddhammasaññatti anattukkaṃsanā aparavambhanā. Evamassime aneke kusalā dhammā sambhavanti sammādiṭṭhipaccayā.
mn60:11.8.eng: And that is how these many skillful qualities come to be with right view as condition—right view, right thought, right speech, not contradicting the noble ones, persuading others to accept true teachings, and not glorifying oneself or putting others down.

mn60:12.1.pli: Tatra, gahapatayo, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati:
mn60:12.1.eng: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:

mn60:12.2.pli: ‘sace kho atthi paro loko, evamayaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:12.2.eng: ‘If there is another world, when this individual’s body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn60:12.3.pli: Kāmaṃ kho pana māhu paro loko, hotu nesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ;
mn60:12.3.eng: But let us grant that those who say that there is no other world are correct.

mn60:12.4.pli: atha ca panāyaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ pāsaṃso—sīlavā purisapuggalo sammādiṭṭhi atthikavādo’ti.
mn60:12.4.eng: Regardless, that individual is still praised by sensible people in this very life as being a moral individual of right view, who affirms a positive teaching.’

mn60:12.5.pli: Sace kho attheva paro loko, evaṃ imassa bhoto purisapuggalassa ubhayattha kaṭaggaho—
mn60:12.5.eng: So if there really is another world, they hold a perfect hand on both counts.
mn60:12.5.comm: “Perfect hand” (kaṭaggaha) is an expression from the classical Vedic game of chance. The details are obscure and would have changed over time, but it seems that a large quantity of vibhītaka (“bedda”) nuts were cast in a hollow, from which players took a handful. If the number of nuts was divisible by four, it was said to be a “perfect” (kaṭa; see Rig Veda 1.132.1, etc.) “hand” (gāha). | Apaṇṇaka and kaṭaggāha are also connected at SN 42.13:23.5; compare the “gem” thrown like a loaded die at AN 3.118:4.6 and AN 10.217:17.1. Good rebirth is further compared to a “perfect hand” at MN 129:49.1. And at Ja 1:2.4, a wise person would “take up” (gaṇhe) what is unfailing, namely a winning hand.

mn60:12.6.pli: yañca diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ pāsaṃso, yañca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:12.6.eng: For they are praised by sensible people in this very life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn60:12.7.pli: Evamassāyaṃ apaṇṇako dhammo susamatto samādinno ubhayaṃsaṃ pharitvā tiṭṭhati, riñcati akusalaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
mn60:12.7.eng: They have rightly undertaken this unfailing teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of both sides, leaving out the unskillful premise.

mn60:13.1.pli: Santi, gahapatayo, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:13.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn60:13.2.pli: ‘karoto kārayato, chindato chedāpayato, pacato pācāpayato, socayato socāpayato, kilamato kilamāpayato, phandato phandāpayato, pāṇamatipātayato, adinnaṃ ādiyato, sandhiṃ chindato, nillopaṃ harato, ekāgārikaṃ karoto, paripanthe tiṭṭhato, paradāraṃ gacchato, musā bhaṇato; karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ.
mn60:13.2.eng: ‘The one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do nothing wrong when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie.
mn60:13.2.comm: At DN 2:17.2, this denial of the doctrine of kamma is attributed to Pūraṇa Kassapa. He may have subscribed to hard determinism, so that we have no choice in what we do. He may also have believed that we should keep moral rules as a social contract, but that this had no effect on the afterlife. | In such contexts, kar- means “punish, inflict” (MN 129:29.2).

mn60:13.3.pli: Khurapariyantena cepi cakkena yo imissā pathaviyā pāṇe ekaṃ maṃsakhalaṃ ekaṃ maṃsapuñjaṃ kareyya, natthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
mn60:13.3.eng: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.

mn60:13.4.pli: Dakkhiṇañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya hananto ghātento, chindanto chedāpento, pacanto pācento; natthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
mn60:13.4.eng: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.

mn60:13.5.pli: Uttarañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya dadanto dāpento, yajanto yajāpento; natthi tatonidānaṃ puññaṃ, natthi puññassa āgamo.
mn60:13.5.eng: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.

mn60:13.6.pli: Dānena damena saṃyamena saccavajjena natthi puññaṃ, natthi puññassa āgamo’ti.
mn60:13.6.eng: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’

mn60:14.1.pli: Tesaṃyeva kho, gahapatayo, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ujuvipaccanīkavādā te evamāhaṃsu:

mn60:14.2.pli: ‘karoto kārayato, chindato chedāpayato, pacato pācāpayato, socayato socāpayato, kilamato kilamāpayato, phandato phandāpayato, pāṇamatipātayato, adinnaṃ ādiyato, sandhiṃ chindato, nillopaṃ harato, ekāgārikaṃ karoto, paripanthe tiṭṭhato, paradāraṃ gacchato, musā bhaṇato; karoto karīyati pāpaṃ.
mn60:14.2.eng: ‘The one who acts does a bad deed when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do a bad deed when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie.

mn60:14.3.eng: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, evil comes of that, and an outcome of evil.

mn60:14.4.pli: Dakkhiṇañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya hananto ghātento, chindanto chedāpento, pacanto pācento; atthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, atthi pāpassa āgamo.
mn60:14.4.eng: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, evil comes of that, and an outcome of evil.

mn60:14.5.eng: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, merit comes of that, and an outcome of merit.

mn60:14.6.pli: Dānena damena saṃyamena saccavajjena atthi puññaṃ, atthi puññassa āgamo’ti.
mn60:14.6.eng: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is merit and outcome of merit.’

mn60:14.8.eng: Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”

mn60:15.1.pli: “Tatra, gahapatayo, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:15.1.eng: “Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

mn60:15.2.pli: ‘karoto kārayato, chindato chedāpayato, pacato pācāpayato, socayato socāpayato, kilamato kilamāpayato, phandato phandāpayato, pāṇamatipātayato, adinnaṃ ādiyato, sandhiṃ chindato, nillopaṃ harato, ekāgārikaṃ karoto, paripanthe tiṭṭhato, paradāraṃ gacchato, musā bhaṇato; karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ.
mn60:15.2.eng: the one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, etc.

mn60:15.3.pli: Khurapariyantena cepi cakkena yo imissā pathaviyā pāṇe ekaṃ maṃsakhalaṃ ekaṃ maṃsapuñjaṃ kareyya, natthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.

mn60:15.4.pli: Dakkhiṇañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya hananto ghātento …pe… dānena damena saṃyamena saccavajjena natthi puññaṃ, natthi puññassa āgamo’ti

mn60:15.5.pli: tesametaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—yamidaṃ kāyasucaritaṃ, vacīsucaritaṃ, manosucaritaṃ—ime tayo kusale dhamme abhinivajjetvā yamidaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ, vacīduccaritaṃ, manoduccaritaṃ—ime tayo akusale dhamme samādāya vattissanti.
mn60:15.5.eng: You can expect that they will shun good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and undertake and implement bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn60:15.7.pli: Na hi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā passanti akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ vodānapakkhaṃ.
mn60:15.7.eng: Because those ascetics and brahmins don’t see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, sordidness, and corruption, or that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.

mn60:16.1.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana kiriyaṃ ‘natthi kiriyā’ tissa diṭṭhi hoti; sāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi.
mn60:16.1.eng: Moreover, since action actually does have an effect, their view that action is ineffective is wrong view.

mn60:16.2.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana kiriyaṃ ‘natthi kiriyā’ti saṅkappeti; svāssa hoti micchāsaṅkappo.
mn60:16.2.eng: Since action actually does have an effect, their thought that action is ineffective is wrong thought.

mn60:16.3.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana kiriyaṃ ‘natthi kiriyā’ti vācaṃ bhāsati; sāssa hoti micchāvācā.
mn60:16.3.eng: Since action actually does have an effect, their speech that action is ineffective is wrong speech.

mn60:16.4.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana kiriyaṃ ‘natthi kiriyā’ti āha, ye te arahanto kiriyavādā tesamayaṃ paccanīkaṃ karoti.
mn60:16.4.eng: Since action actually does have an effect, in saying that action is ineffective they contradict those perfected ones who teach that action is effective.

mn60:16.5.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana kiriyaṃ ‘natthi kiriyā’ti paraṃ saññāpeti; sāssa hoti asaddhammasaññatti.
mn60:16.5.eng: Since action actually does have an effect, in persuading another that action is ineffective they are persuading them to accept an untrue teaching.

mn60:16.6.pli: Tāya ca pana asaddhammasaññattiyā attānukkaṃseti, paraṃ vambheti.
mn60:16.6.eng: And on account of that they glorify themselves and put others down.

mn60:16.7.pli: Iti pubbeva kho panassa susīlyaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, dussīlyaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ—
mn60:16.7.eng: So they give up their former ethical conduct and are established in unethical conduct.

mn60:16.8.pli: ayañca micchādiṭṭhi micchāsaṅkappo micchāvācā ariyānaṃ paccanīkatā asaddhammasaññatti attukkaṃsanā paravambhanā. Evamassime aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti micchādiṭṭhipaccayā.
mn60:16.8.eng: And that is how these many bad, unskillful qualities come to be with wrong view as condition—wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, contradicting the noble ones, persuading others to accept untrue teachings, and glorifying oneself and putting others down.

mn60:17.1.pli: Tatra, gahapatayo, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati:
mn60:17.1.eng: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:

mn60:17.2.pli: ‘sace kho natthi kiriyā, evamayaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo kāyassa bhedā sotthimattānaṃ karissati;
mn60:17.2.eng: ‘If there is no effective action, when this individual’s body breaks up they will keep themselves safe.

mn60:17.3.pli: sace kho atthi kiriyā evamayaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:17.3.eng: And if there is effective action, when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn60:17.4.pli: Kāmaṃ kho pana māhu kiriyā, hotu nesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ;
mn60:17.4.eng: But let us grant that those who say that there is no effective action are correct.

mn60:17.5.pli: atha ca panāyaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ gārayho—dussīlo purisapuggalo micchādiṭṭhi akiriyavādo’ti.
mn60:17.5.eng: Regardless, that individual is still criticized by sensible people in this very life as being an immoral individual of wrong view, one who denies the efficacy of action.’
mn60:17.5.comm: “One who denies the efficacy of action” is akiriyavāda.

mn60:17.6.pli: Sace kho attheva kiriyā, evaṃ imassa bhoto purisapuggalassa ubhayattha kaliggaho—
mn60:17.6.eng: But if there really is effective action, they hold a losing hand on both counts.

mn60:17.7.pli: yañca diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ gārayho, yañca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:17.7.eng: For they are criticized by sensible people in this very life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn60:17.8.pli: Evamassāyaṃ apaṇṇako dhammo dussamatto samādinno, ekaṃsaṃ pharitvā tiṭṭhati, riñcati kusalaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
mn60:17.8.eng: They have wrongly undertaken this unfailing teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of one side only, leaving out the skillful premise.

mn60:21.1.pli: Santi, gahapatayo, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:21.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn60:21.2.eng: ‘There is no cause or reason for the corruption of sentient beings.
mn60:21.2.comm: At DN 2:20.2 this view is attributed to the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla, the founder of the Ājīvikas and teacher of fatalism. It is attributed to Pūraṇa Kassapa at SN 22.60:2.2.

mn60:21.3.eng: Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.

mn60:21.4.pli: Natthi hetu, natthi paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā;
mn60:21.4.eng: There’s no cause or reason for the purification of sentient beings.

mn60:21.5.eng: Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.

mn60:21.6.pli: Natthi balaṃ, natthi vīriyaṃ, natthi purisathāmo, natthi purisaparakkamo;
mn60:21.6.eng: There is no power, no energy, no human strength or vigor.

mn60:21.7.pli: sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedentī’ti.
mn60:21.7.eng: All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.’

mn60:22.3.eng: ‘There is a cause and reason for the corruption of sentient beings.

mn60:24.5.eng: Since there actually is causality, in persuading another that there is no causality they are persuading them to accept an untrue teaching.

mn60:24.6.pli: Tāya ca pana asaddhammasaññattiyā attānukkaṃseti, paraṃ vambheti.
mn60:24.6.eng: And on account of that they glorify themselves and put others down.

mn60:24.7.pli: Iti pubbeva kho panassa susīlyaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, dussīlyaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ—
mn60:24.7.eng: So they give up their former ethical conduct and are established in unethical conduct.

mn60:24.8.pli: ayañca micchādiṭṭhi micchāsaṅkappo micchāvācā ariyānaṃ paccanīkatā asaddhammasaññatti attānukkaṃsanā paravambhanā. Evamassime aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti micchādiṭṭhipaccayā.
mn60:24.8.eng: And that is how these many bad, unskillful qualities come to be with wrong view as condition—wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, contradicting the noble ones, persuading others to accept untrue teachings, and glorifying oneself and putting others down.

mn60:25.1.pli: Tatra, gahapatayo, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati:
mn60:25.1.eng: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:

mn60:25.2.pli: ‘sace kho natthi hetu, evamayaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sotthimattānaṃ karissati;
mn60:25.2.eng: ‘If there is no causality, when this individual’s body breaks up they will keep themselves safe.

mn60:25.3.pli: sace kho atthi hetu, evamayaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:25.3.eng: And if there is causality, when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn60:25.4.pli: Kāmaṃ kho pana māhu hetu, hotu nesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ;
mn60:25.4.eng: But let us grant that those who say that there is no causality are correct.

mn60:25.5.pli: atha ca panāyaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ gārayho—dussīlo purisapuggalo micchādiṭṭhi ahetukavādo’ti.
mn60:25.5.eng: Regardless, that individual is still criticized by sensible people in this very life as being an immoral individual of wrong view, one who denies causality.’
mn60:25.5.comm: “One who denies causality” is ahetukavāda.

mn60:25.6.pli: Sace kho attheva hetu, evaṃ imassa bhoto purisapuggalassa ubhayattha kaliggaho—
mn60:25.6.eng: But if there really is causality, they hold a losing hand on both counts.

mn60:25.7.pli: yañca diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ gārayho, yañca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:25.7.eng: For they are criticized by sensible people in this very life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn60:25.8.pli: Evamassāyaṃ apaṇṇako dhammo dussamatto samādinno, ekaṃsaṃ pharitvā tiṭṭhati, riñcati kusalaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
mn60:25.8.eng: They have wrongly undertaken this unfailing teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of one side only, leaving out the skillful premise.

mn60:26.1.pli: Tatra, gahapatayo, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:26.1.eng: Since this is so, consider those ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

mn60:26.2.eng: there is a cause and reason for the corruption of sentient beings, etc.

mn60:26.4.pli: Atthi hetu, atthi paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā;

mn60:26.6.pli: Atthi balaṃ, atthi vīriyaṃ, atthi purisathāmo, atthi purisaparakkamo; na sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedentī’ti

mn60:26.7.pli: tesametaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—yamidaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ, vacīduccaritaṃ, manoduccaritaṃ—ime tayo akusale dhamme abhinivajjetvā yamidaṃ kāyasucaritaṃ, vacīsucaritaṃ, manosucaritaṃ—ime tayo kusale dhamme samādāya vattissanti.
mn60:26.7.eng: You can expect that they will shun bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and undertake and implement good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

mn60:26.9.pli: Passanti hi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ vodānapakkhaṃ.
mn60:26.9.eng: Because those ascetics and brahmins see that unskillful qualities are full of drawbacks, sordidness, and corruption, and that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.

mn60:27.1.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana hetuṃ ‘atthi hetū’ tissa diṭṭhi hoti; sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
mn60:27.1.eng: Moreover, since there actually is causality, their view that there is causality is right view.

mn60:27.2.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana hetuṃ ‘atthi hetū’ti saṅkappeti; svāssa hoti sammāsaṅkappo.
mn60:27.2.eng: Since there actually is causality, their thought that there is causality is right thought.

mn60:27.3.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana hetuṃ ‘atthi hetū’ti vācaṃ bhāsati; sāssa hoti sammāvācā.
mn60:27.3.eng: Since there actually is causality, their speech that there is causality is right speech.

mn60:27.4.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana hetuṃ ‘atthi hetū’ti āha, ye te arahanto hetuvādā tesamayaṃ na paccanīkaṃ karoti.
mn60:27.4.eng: Since there actually is causality, in saying that there is causality they don’t contradict those perfected ones who teach that there is causality.

mn60:27.5.pli: Santaṃyeva kho pana hetuṃ ‘atthi hetū’ti paraṃ saññāpeti; sāssa hoti saddhammasaññatti.
mn60:27.5.eng: Since there actually is causality, in persuading another that there is causality they are persuading them to accept a true teaching.

mn60:27.6.pli: Tāya ca pana saddhammasaññattiyā nevattānukkaṃseti, na paraṃ vambheti.
mn60:27.6.eng: And on account of that they don’t glorify themselves or put others down.

mn60:27.7.pli: Iti pubbeva kho panassa dussīlyaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, susīlyaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ—
mn60:27.7.eng: So they give up their former unethical conduct and are established in ethical conduct.

mn60:27.8.pli: ayañca sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā ariyānaṃ apaccanīkatā saddhammasaññatti anattukkaṃsanā aparavambhanā. Evamassime aneke kusalā dhammā sambhavanti sammādiṭṭhipaccayā.
mn60:27.8.eng: And that is how these many skillful qualities come to be with right view as condition—right view, right thought, right speech, not contradicting the noble ones, persuading others to accept true teachings, and not glorifying oneself or putting others down.

mn60:28.1.pli: Tatra, gahapatayo, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati: ‘sace kho atthi hetu, evamayaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:28.1.eng: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way: ‘If there is causality, when this individual’s body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn60:28.2.pli: Kāmaṃ kho pana māhu hetu, hotu nesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ;
mn60:28.2.eng: But let us grant that those who say that there is no causality are correct.

mn60:28.3.pli: atha ca panāyaṃ bhavaṃ purisapuggalo diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ pāsaṃso—sīlavā purisapuggalo sammādiṭṭhi hetuvādo’ti.
mn60:28.3.eng: Regardless, that individual is still praised by sensible people in this very life as being a moral individual of right view, who affirms causality.’

mn60:28.4.pli: Sace kho atthi hetu, evaṃ imassa bhoto purisapuggalassa ubhayattha kaṭaggaho—
mn60:28.4.eng: So if there really is causality, they hold a perfect hand on both counts.

mn60:28.5.pli: yañca diṭṭheva dhamme viññūnaṃ pāsaṃso, yañca kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissati.
mn60:28.5.eng: For they are praised by sensible people in this very life, and when their body breaks up, after death, they will be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn60:28.6.pli: Evamassāyaṃ apaṇṇako dhammo susamatto samādinno, ubhayaṃsaṃ pharitvā tiṭṭhati, riñcati akusalaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
mn60:28.6.eng: They have rightly undertaken this unfailing teaching in such a way that it encompasses the positive outcomes of both sides, leaving out the unskillful premise.

mn60:29.1.pli: Santi, gahapatayo, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:29.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn60:29.2.eng: ‘There are no totally formless states of meditation.’
mn60:29.2.comm: The four “formless states” (āruppā) are attained with the “total” (sabbaso) surmounting of form. While the previous views characterize prominent ascetic movements, the final view relates to the formless meditations, the cardinal teaching of the contemplative movement of the Kosalan brahmins, represented by such figures as Āḷāra Kālāma and Uddaka Rāmaputta (MN 36:14.9) or the sixteen brahmins of the Pārāyanavagga (Snp 5.1 ff.). The Buddha elevates his teaching by directly addressing the highest and best of contemporary Brahmanical practices.

mn60:30.1.pli: Tesaṃyeva kho, gahapatayo, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ujuvipaccanīkavādā.
mn60:30.1.eng: And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this.

mn60:30.3.eng: ‘There are totally formless states of meditation.’

mn60:30.5.eng: Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”

mn60:31.1.eng: “A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:

mn60:31.2.pli: ye kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:

mn60:31.3.eng: there are no totally formless meditations, but I have not seen that.

mn60:31.4.pli: yepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:31.4.eng: Some ascetics and brahmins say that

mn60:31.5.eng: there are totally formless meditations, but I have not known that.

mn60:31.6.pli: Ahañceva kho pana ajānanto apassanto ekaṃsena ādāya vohareyyaṃ—
mn60:31.6.eng: Without knowing or seeing, it would not be appropriate for me to take one side and declare,

mn60:31.7.pli: idameva saccaṃ, moghamaññanti, na metaṃ assa patirūpaṃ.
mn60:31.7.eng: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

mn60:31.8.pli: Ye kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:31.8.eng: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that

mn60:31.9.pli: ‘natthi sabbaso āruppā’ti, sace tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati—
mn60:31.9.eng: there are no totally formless meditations are correct, it is possible

mn60:31.10.pli: ye te devā rūpino manomayā, apaṇṇakaṃ me tatrūpapatti bhavissati.
mn60:31.10.eng: that I will be unfailingly reborn among the gods who are formed and made of mind.

mn60:31.11.pli: Ye pana te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:31.11.eng: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that

mn60:31.12.pli: ‘atthi sabbaso āruppā’ti, sace tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati—
mn60:31.12.eng: there are totally formless meditations are correct, it is possible

mn60:31.13.pli: ye te devā arūpino saññāmayā, apaṇṇakaṃ me tatrūpapatti bhavissati.
mn60:31.13.eng: that I will be unfailingly reborn among the gods who are formless and made of perception.

mn60:31.14.eng: Now, owing to form, bad things are seen: taking up the rod and the sword, quarrels, arguments, and disputes, accusations, divisive speech, and lies.

mn60:31.15.eng: But those things don’t exist where it is totally formless.’

mn60:31.16.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya rūpānaṃyeva nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
mn60:31.16.eng: Reflecting like this, they simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding forms.

mn60:32.1.pli: Santi, gahapatayo, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:32.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn60:32.2.eng: ‘There is no such thing as the total cessation of continued existence.’
mn60:32.2.comm: This denies the basic tenet of dependent origination. Bhava means “being”, but in the pregnant philosophical sense of “continued existence”, which often takes the form of “future lives”. It can be broader than that, however, as with the Upaniṣadic doctrine of eternal unity of the contingent personal self with the absolute universal divinity. Since the Brahmins saw the cosmos as an expression of divinity, to them, existence must be inherently good and the cessation of existence abhorrent.

mn60:33.1.pli: Tesaṃyeva kho, gahapatayo, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā ujuvipaccanīkavādā.
mn60:33.1.eng: And there are some ascetics and brahmins whose doctrine directly contradicts this.

mn60:33.3.eng: ‘There is such a thing as the total cessation of continued existence.’

mn60:33.5.eng: Don’t these doctrines directly contradict each other?”

mn60:34.1.eng: “A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:

mn60:34.2.pli: ye kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:

mn60:34.3.eng: there is no such thing as the total cessation of continued existence, but I have not seen that.

mn60:34.4.pli: yepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:34.4.eng: Some ascetics and brahmins say that

mn60:34.5.eng: there is such a thing as the total cessation of continued existence, but I have not known that.

mn60:34.6.pli: Ahañceva kho pana ajānanto apassanto ekaṃsena ādāya vohareyyaṃ—
mn60:34.6.eng: Without knowing or seeing, it would not be appropriate for me to take one side and declare,

mn60:34.7.pli: idameva saccaṃ, moghamaññanti, na metaṃ assa patirūpaṃ.
mn60:34.7.eng: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’

mn60:34.8.pli: Ye kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:34.8.eng: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that

mn60:34.9.pli: ‘natthi sabbaso bhavanirodho’ti, sace tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati—
mn60:34.9.eng: there is no such thing as the total cessation of continued existence are correct, it is possible

mn60:34.10.pli: ye te devā arūpino saññāmayā apaṇṇakaṃ me tatrūpapatti bhavissati.
mn60:34.10.eng: that I will be unfailingly reborn among the gods who are formless and made of perception.

mn60:34.11.pli: Ye pana te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:34.11.eng: If those ascetics and brahmins who say that

mn60:34.12.pli: ‘atthi sabbaso bhavanirodho’ti, sace tesaṃ bhavataṃ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ saccaṃ vacanaṃ, ṭhānametaṃ vijjati—
mn60:34.12.eng: there is such a thing as the total cessation of continued existence are correct, it is possible

mn60:34.13.eng: that I will be fully extinguished in this very life.

mn60:34.14.pli: Ye kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:34.14.eng: The view of those ascetics and brahmins who say that

mn60:34.15.pli: ‘natthi sabbaso bhavanirodho’ti, tesamayaṃ diṭṭhi sārāgāya santike, saṃyogāya santike, abhinandanāya santike, ajjhosānāya santike, upādānāya santike.
mn60:34.15.eng: there is no such thing as the total cessation of continued existence is close to greed, yoking, relishing, attachment, and grasping.

mn60:34.16.pli: Ye pana te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn60:34.16.eng: The view of those ascetics and brahmins who say that

mn60:34.17.pli: ‘atthi sabbaso bhavanirodho’ti, tesamayaṃ diṭṭhi asārāgāya santike, asaṃyogāya santike, anabhinandanāya santike, anajjhosānāya santike, anupādānāya santiketi.
mn60:34.17.eng: there is such a thing as the total cessation of continued existence is close to non-greed, non-yoking, non-relishing, non-attachment, and non-grasping.’

mn60:34.18.pli: So iti paṭisaṅkhāya bhavānaṃyeva nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
mn60:34.18.eng: Reflecting like this, they simply practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding future lives.

mn60:35.1.pli: Cattārome, gahapatayo, puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
mn60:35.1.eng: Householders, these four individuals are found in the world.

mn60:35.3.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco puggalo attantapo hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn60:35.3.eng: One individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

mn60:35.4.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco puggalo parantapo hoti paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn60:35.4.eng: One individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.

mn60:35.5.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco puggalo attantapo ca hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn60:35.5.eng: One individual mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

mn60:35.6.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco puggalo nevattantapo hoti nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
mn60:35.6.eng: One individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.

mn60:35.7.pli: so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
mn60:35.7.eng: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.

mn60:36.1.pli: Katamo ca, gahapatayo, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
mn60:36.1.eng: And what individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves?

mn60:36.2.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco puggalo acelako hoti muttācāro hatthāpalekhano …pe…
mn60:36.2.eng: It’s when a person goes naked, ignoring conventions. …

mn60:36.3.pli: iti evarūpaṃ anekavihitaṃ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
mn60:36.3.eng: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.

mn60:36.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, gahapatayo, puggalo attantapo attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn60:36.4.eng: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

mn60:37.1.pli: Katamo ca, gahapatayo, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
mn60:37.1.eng: And what individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?

mn60:37.2.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco puggalo orabbhiko hoti sūkariko …pe… ye vā panaññepi keci kurūrakammantā.
mn60:37.2.eng: It’s when an individual is a butcher of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood.

mn60:37.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, gahapatayo, puggalo parantapo paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn60:37.3.eng: This is called an individual who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.

mn60:38.1.pli: Katamo ca, gahapatayo, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto?
mn60:38.1.eng: And what individual mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?

mn60:38.2.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, ekacco puggalo rājā vā hoti khattiyo muddhāvasitto …pe…
mn60:38.2.eng: It’s when an individual is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin. He has a new ceremonial hall built to the east of the citadel. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. …
mn60:38.2.comm: Pali here is abbreviated, and I have expanded partially for clarity. For the full text, see MN 51:10.8.

mn60:38.3.pli: tepi daṇḍatajjitā bhayatajjitā assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni karonti.
mn60:38.3.eng: His bondservants, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping, with tearful faces.

mn60:38.4.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, gahapatayo, puggalo attantapo ca attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
mn60:38.4.eng: This is called an individual who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

mn60:39.1.pli: Katamo ca, gahapatayo, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
mn60:39.1.eng: And what individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others,

mn60:39.2.pli: so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati?
mn60:39.2.eng: living without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine?

mn60:40-54.1.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho …
mn60:40-54.1.eng: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …

mn60:40-54.2.eng: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some good family. …

mn60:40-54.3.pli: so ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
mn60:40-54.3.eng: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

mn60:40-54.4.pli: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn60:40-54.4.eng: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption …

mn60:40-54.5.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ …pe…

mn60:55.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn60:55.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives. …

mn60:55.2.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
mn60:55.2.eng: They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

mn60:55.3.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn60:55.3.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.

mn60:55.4.pli: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
mn60:55.4.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. … They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

mn60:55.5.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn60:55.5.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

mn60:55.6.eng: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

mn60:55.7.eng: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.

mn60:55.8.pli: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati.
mn60:55.8.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

mn60:55.9.eng: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn60:55.10.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn60:55.10.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn60:56.1.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, gahapatayo, puggalo nevattantapo nāttaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto;
mn60:56.1.eng: This is called an individual who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.

mn60:56.2.pli: so anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharatī”ti.
mn60:56.2.eng: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.”

mn60:57.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, sāleyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn60:57.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmins and householders of Sālā said to the Buddha,

mn60:57.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
mn60:57.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

mn60:57.4.pli: Ete mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāma dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn60:57.4.eng: We go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
mn60:57.4.comm: They are also said to have gone forth at MN 41:44.4.

mn60:57.5.pli: Upāsake no bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gate”ti.
mn60:57.5.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
